#Text=SHEPTON MALLET.
#Text=Funeral of Lord Palmerston.
#Text=—On Friday last the bells of our parish church rung out a muffled peal in memory to this great statesman.
#Text=High Constable.
#Text=—At a meeting of the Court Leet, at the George Hotel, Mr.

#Text=Kelly, grocer, of this town, was appointed high constable for tho ensuing ye«r. 15th Somerset Rifle Corps. — The unonthly competition for the challenge cup and other prizes took place at the butts on Wednesday last.
#Text=Private Goodman, who made the highest score, did not enter for the cup, and had in consequence to take a minor prize.
#Text=The cup was therefore won by Sergt.
#Text=Butler, .Private Goodman taking the salts and Sergt.
#Text=Cook a gold pencilcase.
#Text=Five Cottages Bubnt Down.
#Text=—Early on Thursday morning the inhabitants of Shepton Mallet were aroused from their slumbers by the cries of fire in Cowlstreet.
#Text=On proceeding to the spot four cottages were found in flames, and despite the heavy rain ths.t was falling at the time, tbey were burnt to the ground before daybreak.
#Text=On Wednesday morning the chimney of one of the cottages caught fire, and it communicated to the roof; but it was put out, ns it was supposed, at the time.
#Text=Early next morning the fire broke out afresh, and the three cottages adjoining, the roofs of which were of thatch, soon caught, and the whole was in a blazing mass.
#Text=It was with great difficulty that tho furniture of the poor cottagers could be got away.
#Text=Not a drop of water could be had, although Shepton Mallet is so abundantly supplied.
#Text=The parish engines, too, are out of repair, and are carefully locked up.
#Text=Another cottage was burnt to the ground on Thursday afternoon.
#Text=It was adjoining those that were burnt on Thursday morning.
#Text=One poor boy, by the name of Emery, nearly lost bis life in endeavouring to extinguish the flames.
#Text=It appears he was on one of the side walls, when suddenly it gave way, and ho was precipitated into the burning mass below.
